entry.content:
Task 0: Preparation

Check the connection

We have put the jumper header to the GND ports, and then connected the Bulb board on the PyBench.

Put the pybench settings to 101, and then adjusted the bulb board into 1.80V.

Task 1: DC Characteristic of the Bulb Board

Preparation

Before we start Task 1, we‚Äôve used the code to check the bulb voltage captured by the phototransistor.

We sent 1.5V to the bulb, and received 1.6871V as return.

We have adjusted the voltage to 1.8v, but received 1.6871v, so we think maybe it‚Äôs because the bulb is not prepared. so we‚Äôve changed the pause(1); to pause(3); and we get 1.7643v.

Method

The Bulb Board was driven using a DC voltage generated by the DAC on the PyBench board and controlled via MATLAB.
For each input voltage xdc‚Äã, the system was allowed to settle for 0.5 s to ensure that transient effects had decayed and that the output had reached steady state.

The output voltage ydc‚Äã, corresponding to the light intensity measured by the phototransistor and amplifier, was then sampled multiple times and averaged to reduce noise.
This procedure was repeated over a range of input voltages between 0 V and approximately 2.5 V, and the resulting DC input‚Äìoutput characteristic was plotted.

Results

The measured DC input‚Äìoutput characteristic is shown in Figure 1.

  • For low input voltages (below approximately 0.5), the output voltage remains close to zero and the light bulb does not emit visible light.

  • In the mid-range of input voltage (approximately 0.7-1.6), the output increases rapidly with input voltage.

  • At higher input voltages (above approximately 1.6V), the output voltage saturates at around 2.1V, and further increases in input voltage produce little change in output.

Task 2: Frequency Response of the Bulb Board system ‚Äì Theoretical only

System Model

For the purpose of theoretical analysis, the Bulb Board is modelled as a linear time-invariant (LTI) system, with non-linear DC effects neglected.
The overall system is represented as two subsystems connected in series:

  1. A second-order oscillatory electronic circuit, described by the transfer function

H(s)=1000/s2+5s+1000‚Äã

  1. A first-order system representing the light bulb, detector and amplifier, described by

B(s)=1/0.038s+1

The overall transfer function of the system is therefore given by:

G(s)=H(s)B(s)=1000‚Äã/0.038s3+1.19s2+43s+1000

For the results, we get this diagram as result.

Task 3: Measure the Frequency Response of the Bulb Board system using PyBench

Method

To approximate linear system behaviour, the Bulb Board was operated within a small-signal region identified from the DC characteristic in Task 1.
The input signal was constrained to oscillate between 1.45 V and 1.55 V, ensuring that the system operated within an approximately linear region.

A sinusoidal input signal was generated using the DAC on the PyBench board and controlled via MATLAB.
For each test frequency, the output voltage corresponding to the measured light intensity was sampled at a sampling frequency of 100 Hz, and a sufficient number of samples were collected to capture steady-state behaviour.

The system gain at each frequency was calculated using the ratio of the output peak-to-peak voltage to the input peak-to-peak voltage:

‚à£G(jœâ)‚à£=xpp‚Äãypp‚Äã‚Äã

The gain was then converted to decibels using:

GdB‚Äã=20log10‚Äã‚à£G(jœâ)‚à£

Measurements were initially performed at selected frequencies (1 Hz, 3 Hz, 4 Hz, 5 Hz, 7 Hz and 9 Hz), and subsequently automated to obtain measurements over the frequency range 1‚Äì20 Hz in steps of 1 Hz.

Results

The measured frequency response shows the following trends:

  • At low frequencies, the measured gain remains approximately constant, indicating that the output closely follows the input signal.

  • A peak in gain is observed at approximately 4hz and 5hz, corresponding to resonant behaviour of the system.

  • At higher frequencies, the gain decreases rapidly, indicating significant attenuation of high-frequency input signals.

When compared with the theoretical frequency response obtained in Task 2, the overall shape of the measured response is similar, including the presence of a resonant peak and high-frequency roll-off. However, discrepancies in gain magnitude and peak sharpness are observed.

Task 3a

Method

An automated MATLAB script was developed to measure the system gain at frequencies ranging from 1 Hz to 20 Hz in steps of 1 Hz.
At each frequency, a small-amplitude sinusoidal input signal was applied, with the operating point constrained between 1.45 V and 1.55 V to ensure approximately linear system behaviour.

For each frequency, the output signal was sampled at a fixed sampling frequency and the steady-state portion of the signal was analysed.
The system gain was calculated using the ratio of output to input peak-to-peak amplitudes and converted to decibels.
The measured gain values were then plotted as a function of frequency to obtain the experimental frequency response of the system.

Results

The measured frequency response obtained from the automated sweep shows a clear resonant peak and a gradual roll-off at higher frequencies.
The overall shape of the experimental frequency response closely resembles the theoretical prediction from Task 2.

However, differences are observed in the magnitude of the gain and the sharpness of the resonant peak. In particular:

  • The measured peak gain is lower than the theoretical value.

  • The resonant peak appears broader and less pronounced than predicted.

  • High-frequency attenuation is stronger in the measured response.

We have also combined the prediction with the actual diagram.

Task 4: Step Response of the Bulb Board

Method

The Bulb Board was driven using step changes in input voltage generated by the DAC on the PyBench board and controlled via MATLAB.
A rising step from 0.7 V to 1.2 V was first applied, followed by a falling step from 1.2 V back to 0.7 V.

The output voltage, corresponding to the measured light intensity, was sampled at a fixed sampling frequency, and the transient response was recorded over a sufficient duration to capture the full system response, including oscillations and settling behaviour.

Results

The measured step response exhibits clear transient dynamics.

Following the rising step input, the output voltage increases rapidly and overshoots the final steady-state value before undergoing oscillations that gradually decay with time.
A similar oscillatory behaviour is observed following the falling step, although the amplitude and shape of the response differ slightly due to the asymmetric behaviour of the physical system.

After the transient oscillations decay, the output settles to a steady-state value consistent with the DC characteristic obtained in Task 1.

entry.content:
Task 1: Connecting Pybench to PC

Check the connection

In task 1, we have connected our Pybench to the PC, and we‚Äôve seen the disk in our File explorer.

Self-Test

Procedure

  • Set the DIP switch to 110

  • Pressed the RESET button on the PyBench board

  • Observed the OLED display

  • Pressed the USR button to cycle through self-test modes

Observation

  • OLED displayed ‚ÄúPyBench Self-Test‚Äù after reset

  • First press of USR button:

    • Real-time microphone waveform displayed

    • Signal amplitude changed in response to ambient sound

  • Second press:

    • Accelerometer test showing pitch and roll values when tilting the board

Conclusion

  • Microphone, ADC, OLED display, and IMU are operating correctly

  • PyBench hardware passed the built-in self-test

Task 2: Signal Generation

Sine Wave

  • Time domain: smooth periodic waveform

  • Frequency domain: single dominant peak at the fundamental frequency

  • Minimal harmonic content

Triangle Wave

  • Time domain: linear rising and falling edges

  • Frequency domain: odd harmonics present

  • Harmonic amplitudes decrease rapidly with frequency

Square Wave

  • Time domain: sharp transitions

  • Frequency domain: strong odd harmonics

  • Harmonics decay more slowly than triangle wave

Sine Wave with lower freq

  • Time domain: smoother periodic waveform

  • Frequency domain: lower frequency

Task 3: Microphone Signal Capture and Spectrum Analysis

Method

  • Created lab2task3.m to acquire microphone samples

  • Set sampling frequency and number of samples

  • Removed DC offset before FFT

  • Used plot_spec to compute frequency spectrum

  • Modified code to run continuously using a while loop

Tests

Normal Signal

  • The sound signal recorded when we‚Äôre doing the lab
  • People are talking

Whistling Signal

  • Spectrum shows a clear dominant peak at the sound frequency

Task 4: Windowing Effect on Signal Spectrum

Method

  • Replaced plot_spec with plot_spec_dB to display spectrum in dB

  • Captured tuning fork signals at 1000 Hz and 1100 Hz

  • Applied Hamming window before FFT

  • Compared spectra with and without windowing

Observations

Without Window (Rectangular Window)

  • Significant spectral leakage around the main peak

  • Energy spreads into adjacent frequency bins

  • Nearby frequencies are difficult to distinguish

With Hamming Window

  • Reduced spectral leakage

  • Main peak becomes cleaner and more localized

  • Adjacent frequency components are easier to separate

Key Findings

  • Truncating a signal is equivalent to applying a rectangular window

  • Windowing reduces spectral leakage at the cost of peak widening

  • Hamming window improves frequency discrimination in practice

Task 5: Music Signal Segmentation and Analysis

Method

  • Loaded two_drums.wav (fs = 44.1 kHz)

  • Divided signal into 20 ms segments

  • Computed energy for each segment

  • Used findpeaks to detect energy maxima

  • Analysed frequency content of drum hits

  • Tried other files to test the code

Observations

Energy Segmentation

  • Energy peaks correspond to individual drum hits

  • Peaks clearly separate two different rhythmic events

Frequency Analysis

  • Each drum exhibits a distinct dominant frequency range

  • Lower-frequency drum shows broader spectral content

Drum

Bass

Key Findings

  • Short-time energy effectively segments percussive signals

  • findpeaks reliably identifies transient sound events

  • Different instruments can be distinguished spectrally

entry.content:
Task 1 ‚Äì Sinusoidal Signal Generation

Created a Matlab function sine_gen.m to generate a sinewave with given amplitude, frequency, sampling rate, and duration.

Generate a sine wave

Observation

‚Ä¢ The generated waveform is periodic and smooth.

‚Ä¢ Increasing frequency results in more oscillations over the same time window.

‚Ä¢ Sampling frequency controls time resolution of the plotted signal.

Learning

‚Ä¢ Matlab functions can be used to encapsulate signal generation.

‚Ä¢ Discrete-time signals are represented as sampled versions of continuous signals.

Task 2 ‚Äì Spectrum of a Signal

Implemented plot_spec.m using Matlab‚Äôs FFT function to plot the frequency spectrum of a sinewave.

Observation

‚Ä¢ A pure 400 Hz sinewave produces a clear peak at 400 Hz in the frequency domain.

‚Ä¢ The spectrum is symmetric around zero frequency.

‚Ä¢ Higher sampling frequency increases frequency resolution.

Learning

‚Ä¢ FFT converts a signal from time domain to frequency domain.

‚Ä¢ Pure tones correspond to single frequency components.

Task 3 ‚Äì Two-Tone Signal

Generated two sinewaves:

‚Ä¢ s1: 400 Hz, amplitude 1.0

‚Ä¢ s2: 1000 Hz, amplitude 0.5

and added them together.

Observation

‚Ä¢ Time-domain waveform becomes more complex due to superposition.

‚Ä¢ Frequency spectrum shows two distinct peaks at 400 Hz and 1000 Hz.

Learning

‚Ä¢ Linear systems allow signals to be added directly.

‚Ä¢ Frequency components remain separable in the spectrum.

Task 4 ‚Äì Two Tones with Noise

Added Gaussian noise using randn(size(sig)) to the two-tone signal.

Observation

‚Ä¢ Time-domain signal becomes irregular.

‚Ä¢ Frequency spectrum still shows the main frequency peaks, but with a raised noise floor.

Learning

‚Ä¢ Noise affects signal clarity but dominant frequencies can still be identified.

‚Ä¢ Frequency-domain analysis is more robust to noise than time-domain inspection.

Task 5 ‚Äì Projection Using Dot Product

Computed dot products between different sinusoidal signals.

Results

‚Ä¢ Dot product of s1 (400 Hz) and s2 (1000 Hz) = 1.8789e-13

‚Ä¢ Dot product of s1 (400 Hz) and s3 (401 Hz) =-1.9702e-10

‚Ä¢ Dot product of (s1 + s2) with s1 = 5000

Learning

‚Ä¢ Sinusoids of different frequencies are orthogonal over a full period.

‚Ä¢ Dot product measures similarity between signals.

‚Ä¢ Projection shows how much of one signal exists within another.

Task 6 ‚Äì PyBench Board as Spectrum Analyser

Used the PyBench board to display the FFT of microphone input on the OLED screen.

Observation

‚Ä¢ The spectrum updates in real time when a pure tone is played.

‚Ä¢ Peaks correspond to the frequency of the input sound.

‚Ä¢ Display range is 0‚Äì5 kHz with magnitude shown in dB.

Learning

‚Ä¢ FFT can be implemented on embedded hardware in real time.

‚Ä¢ Frequency-domain analysis is useful for real-world signal inspection.

entry.title: Electronics 2 Logbook
entry.content:
Welcome to the Electronics 2 Laboratory Logbook.
This website documents my laboratory work for the Electronics 2 module, including experimental objectives, theoretical background, circuit design, measurements, results, and reflections.

Portals

Lab 1 Linküëá

Lab_1

This lab introduces basic signal processing concepts by using Matlab and embedded hardware to generate, analyse, and interpret signals in both the time and frequency domains.

Lab 2 Linküëá

Lab_2

This lab introduces fundamental signal processing concepts using MATLAB. Key topics include sinusoidal signal generation, frequency spectrum analysis using FFT, multi-tone signals, noise effects, windowing effects and signal orthogonality through projection. The lab also includes a hardware-based spectrum analysis demonstration using the PyBench board, linking theoretical concepts to real-world signal measurement.

Lab 3 Linküëá

Lab_3

This laboratory characterises the dynamic behaviour of a physical system by experimentally and theoretically analysing its DC response, frequency response, and transient step response using linear system models.
